question: Ðæt maden (bitan) #### alcne ðe heo geracan mihte — The maiden bit anything she could reach
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'bitan' is in the third person singular past form 'bat' because the subject is 'Ðæt maden'

question: Mycel yfel deð se ðe leas (writan) #### — Much evil does he who writes falsely
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'writan' is in the third person singular present form 'writ' because the subject is 'se'

question: Ðu (ripan) #### ðine æceras — You reap your acres
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'ripan' is in the second person singular present form 'ripst' because the subject is 'Ðu'

question: Ða ealdan preostas cealf (sniþan) #### — The old priests slaughtered a calf
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'ripan' is in the second person singular present form 'ripst' because the subject is 'Ðu'

question: He ofer sæ (liþan) #### in Gallia rice — He travelled over the sea to the Kingdom of the Gauls
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'liþan' is in the third person singular past form 'laþ' because the subject is 'He'

question: Gif we eow ða gastlican sad sawaþ, hwonlic biþ ðæt we eowere flaslican þing (ripan) #### — If we sow the spiritual seeds for you, it is little matter that we reaped your fleshly goods
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'ripan' is in the plural past form 'ripon' because the subject is 'we'

question: Hwilum ic on wloncum wicge (ridan) #### — Sometimes I ride on a proud horse
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'ridan' is in the first person singular present form 'ride' because the subject is 'I'

question: Hie (bidan) #### Drihtnes domes — They await the Lord's doom
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'bidan' is in the plural form 'beodaþ' because the subject is 'They'

question: Ða wicingas (drifan) #### us to ðære sæ — The Vikings drive us to the sea
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'drifan' is in the third person singular present form 'drifaþ' because the subject is 'Ða wicingas'

question: Heofenes gim (glidan) #### ofer grundas — Heaven's gem glided over the earth
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'glidan' is in the third person singular past form 'glad' because the subject is 'Heofenes gim'

question: Se bera on ðæm wudu (scitan) #### — The bear defecated in the woods
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'scitan' is in the third person singular past form 'scat' because the subject is 'Se bera'

question: An ðeof ofer þone geard (stigan) #### ond stæll þa wyrta — A thief climbed over the hedge and stole the plants
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'stigan' is in the third person singular past form 'stag' because the subject is 'An ðeof'

question: Heo (bidan) #### soþra gehata — She awaited faithful promises
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'bidan' is in the third person singular past form 'bad' because the subject is 'Heo'

question: Hie (drifan) #### hine onweg — They drove him away
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'drifan' is in the plural form 'drifon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Ðeos bat (glidan) #### on laguflode — This boat glides over the ocean
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'glidan' is in the third person singular present form 'glit' because the subject is 'Ðeos bat'

commonMistakes.explanation: Don't forget, whenever conjugation produces 'dþ', it is changed to 'tt' so 'glidan' becomes 'glitt'
Don't forget, whenever conjugation produces 'dþ', it is changed to 'tt' so 'glidan' becomes 'glitt'

question: (bitan) #### hine lys — Lice bit him
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'bitan' is in the plural past form 'biton' because the subject is 'lys'

question: Edmund þis boc (writan) #### — Edmund wrote this book
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'writan' is in the third person singular past form 'wrat' because the subject is 'Edmund'

question: Ða hie heora corn (ripan) #### — When they reap their grain
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'ripan' is in the plural past form 'ripon' because the subject is 'hie'

question: Heo mec (sniþan) #### seaxes ecg — She cut me with the blade of the knife
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'sniþan' is in the third person singular present form 'snaþ' because the subject is 'Heo'

question: We ofer laguflode scipas (liþan) #### — We sailed ships over the ocean
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'liþan' is in the plural past form 'lidon' because the subject is 'We'

question: Sum mon (ridan) #### be ðære stowe — A certain man rode to the holy place
explanation: Here the Class I verb 'ridan' is in the third person singular past form 'rad' because the subject is 'Sum mon'

question: He (beodan) #### Iosepe ðæt he hit bude his broðrum — He proclimed to Joseph that he should offer it to his brothers
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'beodan' is in the third person singular past form 'bead' because the subject is 'He'

question: Heremod (breotan) #### bolgen-mod giefstol — Heremod, in an angry mood, broke his throne
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'breotan' is in the third person singular past form 'breat' because the subject is 'Heremod'

question: Hie (ceowan) #### heora girdlas, and gærs æton — They chewed their girdles and ate grass
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'ceowan' is in the plural past form 'cuwon' because the subject is 'Hie'

explanation: Here the Class II verb 'cleofan' is in the plural past form 'clufon' because the subject is 'Sibyrhtes broðor ond swiðe mænig oþer'

question: Se biþ mihtigra se ðe gaþ ðonne se ðe (creopan) #### — He who walks is more powerful than he who creeps

Don't forget 'dreogan' undergoes i-mutation in the third person present singular to become 'driegð'

question: Ða englas twegen him on twa healfa (fleogan) #### — The two angels flew on both sides of him
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'fleogan' is in the third person singular past form 'flugon' because the subject is 'Ða englas'

question: He (geotan) #### ðæt blod uppan ðæt weofod — He poured blood upon that altar
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'geotan' is in the third person singular past form 'geat' because the subject is 'He'

question: Her begann se deofol to reccanne halige gewrita and he (leogan) #### mid ðære race — Here the devil began to recount holy writings, and he lied in the storytelling
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'leogan' is in the third person singular past form 'leag' because the subject is 'He'

question: He (lutan) #### forþ ðæt him man asloh ðæt heafod of — He bent forward so that his head was cut off
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'lutan' is in the third person singular past form 'leat' because the subject is 'He'

question: Ic (brucan) #### moddrenum flaesce — I enjoy the motherly flesh
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'brucan' is in the first person singular present form 'bruce' because the subject is 'Ic'

question: Heo (lutan) #### to siege ond he sloh þa to mid eallum mægene — She bent to receive the blow, and he struck at her with all his might
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'lutan' is in the third person singular past form 'leat' because the subject is 'Heo'

question: Gif mon (seoþan) #### garleac on henne broþe ond selð drincan þonne tolæt hio þæt sar — If a man boils garlic in hen-stock and gives to drink then it lessens the pain
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'seoþan' is in the third person singular present form 'sieþ' because the subject is 'mon'

explanation: Here the Class II verb 'dreogan' is in the second person singular present form 'driegst' because the subject is 'ðu'

question: Hie (fleogan) #### mid ðam feondum — They flee with the fiends
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'fleogan' is in the plural form 'fleogaþ' because the subject is 'Hie'

explanation: Here the Class II verb 'beodan' is in the plural past form 'budon' because the subject is 'Geacas'

question: Hit mid feðerhoman (fleogan) #### — It flew with feathered wings
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'fleogan' is in the third person singular past form 'fleag' because the subject is 'Hit'

explanation: Here the Class II verb 'seoþan' is in the third person singular past form 'seaþ' because the subject is 'Ðæt ealde wif'

question: Hie þe hira lifes þurh lust (brucan) #### — They who spent their lives in pleasure
explanation: Here the Class II verb 'brucan' is in the plural past form 'brucon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Ða munecas (creopan) #### under ðæm bedde — The monks crept under the bed

question: We æton and (drincan) #### beforan ðe — We ate and drank before you
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'drincan' is in the plural past form 'druncon' because the subject is 'We'

question: Ðu monegum (helpan) #### — You help many
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'helpan' is in the second person singular present form 'helpst' because the subject is 'Ða munecas'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'feohtan' is in the plural past form 'fuhton' because the subject is 'Stuf ond Wihtgar'

question: Ic astigie min scyp ond (weorpan) #### max mine on ea — I get into a boat, and throw my nets in the river
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'weorpan' is in the first person singular present form 'weorpe' because the subject is 'Ic'

question: He ðe mid wite (gieldan) #### — He repays you with punishment
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'gieldan' is in the third person singular present form 'gielt' because the subject is 'he'

Don't forget, whenever conjugation produces 'tþ' after another consonant, it is changed to 't' so 'gieldan' becomes 'gielt'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'bindan' is in the first person singular present form 'binde' because the subject is 'ic'

question: Seo burh (sincan) #### on eorþan — The town sank into the earth
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'sincan' is in the third person singular past form 'sanc' because the subject is 'Seo burh'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'singan' is in the third person singular present form 'singð' because the subject is 'Se fugol'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'swimman' is in the first person singular past form 'swom' because the subject is 'ic'

question: Ge (belgan) #### wið me forðam þe ic gehælde anne man on restedæge — You are angry with me because I cured a man on a Sabbath
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'belgan' is in the plural form 'belgaþ' because the subject is 'Ge'

question: Hie (delfan) #### ane mycle dic — They dug a great ditch
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'delfan' is in the plural past form 'dulfon' because the subject is 'Ge'

question: Swa weax (meltan) ####, gif hit byð wearmum — So wax melts if it is warm
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'meltan' is in the third person singular present form 'milt' because the subject is 'weax'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'melcan' is in the first person singular present form 'melce' because the subject is 'ic'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'swelgan' is in the third person singular past form 'swealg' because the subject is 'Se draca'

question: Se cyning ne (drincan) #### win ne beor — the king drank neither wine nor beer

question: Ðu (drincan) #### seftne drenc ond swetne — You drank a mild and sweet drink
explanation: Here the Class III verb 'drincan' is in the second person singular past form 'drunce' because the subject is 'Ðu'

explanation: Here the Class III verb 'feohtan' is in the third person singular past form 'feaht' because the subject is 'Guðlac'

question: Ðu (wascan) #### þas wyrte — You wash this plant
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'wascan' is in the second person singular form 'wæscst' because the subject is 'Þu'

question: Simon Petrus (dragan) #### ðæt nett on eorþe — Simon Petrus dragged the net ashore
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'dragan' is in the third person singular past form 'drog' because the subject is 'Simon'

question: Hie (dragan) #### heora scipa on, west—healfe ðære brycge — They dragged their ships to the west side of the bridge
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'dragan' is in the plural past form 'drogon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Ðu (dragan) #### þin sweord ond þa fæmna þu ofsloge — You drew your sword and slayed the woman
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'dragan' is in the second person singular past form 'droge' because the subject is 'Þu'

question: His heafod hie (dragan) #### geond þa burh — They dragged his head through the town
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'dragan' is in the plural past form 'drogon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: He me aðas (swerian) #### — He swore oaths to me
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'swerian' is in the third person singular past form 'swor' because the subject is 'He'

question: Hie (swerian) #### him betweonan, ðæt hig sibbe heoldon — They swore oaths between them that they would keep the peace
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'swerian' is in the plural past form 'swor' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Swa swa ðu (swerian) #### on soðfæstnysse ðine — Just as you swore in your faithfulness
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'swerian' is in the second person singular past form 'swore' because the subject is 'ðu'

question: Ðu (ofersteppan) #### ðæm weall — You stepped over the wall
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'ofersteppan' is in the second person singular past form 'oferstope' because the subject is 'ðu'

question: Ða apostoli ða (hliehhan) #### ðæra deofla leasunga — The apostles then laughed at the devil's deception
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'hliehhan' is in the plural past form 'hlogon' because the subject is 'Ða apostoli'

question: (hliehhan) #### þa modi man — The bold man then laughed
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'hliehhan' is in the third person singular past form 'hlog' because the subject is 'þa modi man'

question: Ðonne þu (hliehhan) ####, þonne weop ic biterlice — When you laughed, then I wept bitterly
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'hliehhan' is in the second person singular past form 'hloge' because the subject is 'þu'

question: On ðam ilcan geare he (forþfaran) #### — In that same year he passed away
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'forþfaran' is in the third person singular past form 'forþfor' because the subject is 'he'

question: Hie (forþfaran) #### in þæm gefeohte — They died in that fight
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'forþfaran' is in the plural past form 'forþforon' because the subject is 'hie'

question: Hie (slean) #### fram eastsæ oð westsæ — They slaughtered from the east sea to the west sea
explanation: Here the Class VI verb 'slean' is in the plural past form 'slogon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Ge ne me (cnawan) #### — You do not know me
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'cnawan' is in the plural present form 'cnawaþ' because the subject is 'Ge'

question: Hwi ne (cnawan) #### þu mine spræce? — Why don't you comprehend my speech?
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'cnawan' is in the second person singular present form 'cnæwst' because the subject is 'þu'

question: Ic na (cnawan) #### þis wif! — I don't know this woman!
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'cnawan' is in the first person singular present form 'cnawe' because the subject is 'Ic'

question: We þone biscop ne (cnawan) #### — We knew the bishop not
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'cnawan' is in the plural past form 'cneowon' because the subject is 'We'

question: On lencten hit (growan) ####, ond on hærfest hit wealwað — In lent it grows, and at harvest it fades
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'growan' is in the third person singular present form 'grewð' because the subject is 'hit'

question: Ðæt geonge treow (growan) #### — The young tree grew
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'growan' is in the third person singular past form 'greow' because the subject is 'Ðæt geonge treow'

question: Ic nu (growan) #### swa þæt treow þe mid wæstmum bið fægre gefrætwod — I now grew like the tree that is beautifully adorned with fruit
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'growan' is in the first person singular past form 'greow' because the subject is 'Ic'

question: Hie (growan) #### on eorþan — They grew on the earth
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'growan' is in the plural past form 'greowon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Hit (hleapan) #### on unsmeðe eorðan — It leaped over rough ground
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hleapan' is in the third person singular past form 'hleop' because the subject is 'Hit'

question: He (hleapan) #### on þæs cyninges stedan — He jumped on the king's steed
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hleapan' is in the third person singular past form 'hleop' because the subject is 'He'

question: Her Eadwine eorl ond Morkere eorl (hleapan) #### ut — Here Earls Edwin and Morkere fled away
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hleapan' is in the plural past form 'hleopon' because the subject is 'Edwine ond Morkere'

question: Se wind suþan (blawan) #### — The wind blew from the south
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'blawan' is in the third person singular past form 'bleow' because the subject is 'Se wind'

question: Sona þæs þe he on scyp eode, (blawan) #### westwind — As soon as he went on the ship, the westwind blew
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'blawan' is in the third person singular past form 'bleow' because the subject is 'westwind'

question: Seo byme (blawan) ####, ond ða deadan arisað — The trumpet blows and the dead rise
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'blawan' is in the third person singular present form 'blæwð' because the subject is 'Seo byme'

question: Hie ne þa byman (blawan) #### — They did not blow the trumpets
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'blawan' is in the plural past form 'bleowon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: (blawan) #### se engel on hie — The angel blew on them
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'blawan' is in the third person singular present form 'bleow' because the subject is 'se engel'

question: Drihten hwæt (hatan) #### ðu me don — Lord, what do you command me to do?
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hatan' is in the second person singular present form 'hætst' because the subject is 'ðu'

question: He (hatan) #### englas him to cuman — He ordered angels to come to him
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hatan' is in the third person singular past form 'het' because the subject is 'He'

question: We dydon swa ðu us (hatan) #### — We did as you ordered us
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hatan' is in the second person singular past form 'hete' because the subject is 'ðu'

question: Romane hie tictatores (hatan) #### — Romans called them dictators
explanation: Here the Class VII verb 'hatan' is in the plural past form 'heton' because the subject is 'Romane'
